skill.name: using-superpowers
skill.description: Use when starting any conversation - establishes how to find and use skills, requiring Skill tool invocation before ANY response including clarifying questions
skill.summary: Workflow guidance skill for proper skill selection and invocation before responding to users
skill.author: Cycleaddict

security_audit.summary: All 14 static findings are false positives. The static scanner misinterpreted markdown documentation syntax (backticks, code blocks, Graphviz diagrams) as code patterns. This skill contains only workflow documentation with no executable code, network calls, or system access.

content.value_statement: Claude sometimes skips skill checks and acts directly. This skill enforces disciplined skill invocation by requiring users to read relevant skill files before responding, ensuring proper workflows are followed.
actual_capabilities: Enforces skill file reading before any response or action
Provides decision flowchart for when to invoke skills
Lists common rationalization patterns that indicate skill checks were skipped
Establishes skill priority order between process and implementation skills
Distinguishes between rigid and flexible skill types
Ensures clarifying questions also follow skill workflows
limitations: This is a meta-skill that governs skill selection, not a domain-specific skill
Does not automatically discover applicable skills - users must identify relevant skills
Cannot enforce its own rules - relies on users and AI to follow the guidance
Does not provide domain-specific implementation details

use_cases.title: New Conversation Setup
use_cases.description: When starting any new conversation, read this skill first to establish the discipline of checking for applicable skills before taking any action.
use_cases.target_user: Users who want consistent, skill-guided responses from Claude

use_cases.title: Workflow Enforcement
use_cases.description: Use when you notice responses are skipping established skill workflows. The skill provides specific red flags that indicate rationalization away from proper skill usage.
use_cases.target_user: Teams maintaining quality standards in AI interactions

use_cases.title: Skill Discovery Guide
use_cases.description: Reference when uncertain about skill selection. The skill provides clear guidance on reading skill files, announcing skill usage, and following skill checklists.
use_cases.target_user: New Claude Code users learning the skill ecosystem

prompt_templates.title: Check for Skills First
prompt_templates.prompt: I need to respond to this user request. Before I do anything, read and apply the using-superpowers skill to ensure I follow proper skill invocation procedures. What skills might apply here?
prompt_templates.scenario: When uncertain whether any skills apply to a user request

prompt_templates.title: Enforce Workflow Discipline
prompt_templates.prompt: I'm about to start working on this task. Apply the using-superpowers skill to check if I should be using any other skills first. List the skills I should consider and why.
prompt_templates.scenario: When starting a new task and wanting to ensure proper skill usage

prompt_templates.title: Review Rationalization Patterns
prompt_templates.prompt: Before I respond to this request, apply the using-superpowers skill red flags table. Am I rationalizing my way out of using any applicable skills?
prompt_templates.scenario: When feeling confident about a response and wanting to verify skill check was done

prompt_templates.title: Skill Priority Resolution
prompt_templates.prompt: Multiple skills might apply to this task. Use the using-superpowers skill to determine the correct priority order between process skills and implementation skills.
prompt_templates.scenario: When multiple skills could apply and priority is unclear

output_examples.input: User asks: 'Write a function to calculate fibonacci numbers'
output_examples.output: Before responding, I should check if any skills apply. The using-superpowers skill says to read skill files when there is even a 1% chance a skill applies. For coding tasks, I should check for skills like debugging, tdd, or coding-best-practices. Let me read the relevant skill files first.

output_examples.input: User asks: 'Help me debug this error'
output_examples.output: Using the using-superpowers workflow: First, I need to identify applicable skills. A debugging skill likely exists that provides structured debugging procedures. I should read that skill before proceeding. The using-superpowers skill is clear: if there is any chance a skill applies, I must read it first.

best_practices: Always read skill files before responding, even for simple questions - the skill itself tells you if it applies
Announce which skill you are using and its purpose before proceeding with the task
Follow skill checklists exactly for rigid skills, and adapt principles for flexible skills
Treat skill usage as mandatory, not optional - do not rationalize your way out of checking
anti_patterns: Responding directly without checking for applicable skills first
Assuming you remember how a skill works without reading the current version
Skipping skills because they seem 'overkill' for simple tasks
Gathering information before checking which skills guide information gathering

faq.question: When should I invoke this skill?
faq.answer: Invoke this skill at the start of every conversation or when unsure whether other skills apply. The skill itself says to check if there is even a 1% chance any skill might apply.

faq.question: Does this skill do anything besides provide guidance?
faq.answer: No. This is a meta-skill that contains only workflow documentation. It does not execute code, access files, or perform any actions beyond instructing you to read other skill files.

faq.question: What if I am certain no skills apply?
faq.answer: The skill provides guidance: only skip skill reading when you are definitively certain no skill applies. When uncertain, always read the skill files first.

faq.question: How do I know which skills to check?
faq.answer: Review your available skills in the skills/ directory. If a skill name or description seems relevant to the user request, read that skill file to confirm whether it applies.

faq.question: What are process vs implementation skills?
faq.answer: Process skills like brainstorming or debugging determine HOW to approach a task. Implementation skills like frontend-design guide execution. Process skills take priority when both could apply.

faq.question: Can I skip this skill for simple tasks?
faq.answer: No. The skill explicitly states this is not optional. Simple tasks often become complex, and skills prevent undisciplined action. Always check for applicable skills first.
